title: Monday, 16th April, 2018
bodyHTML:

........ We can waffle on about the breakup values and propco-opco stuff and such in a bit, but first, my question is: why now?

Groundhog Day @BE Good morning, hope you had a good weekend! Just one note - your market write up on Friday mentioned rumors on Shire that the bid was off, but you seemed to imply the opposite (always cautious of course) in the chat earlier that day. What caused the change in tone? Or were you referring to the tweet that sent the stock down in your market write up, which seems a bit of a far fetched "rumor"? Thanks! And sorry for the question right off the bat that isn't related to Whitbread. Just seemed interesting

Whitbread shares have flatlined for several years.

Lemmy Remember some sellside on Whitbread last year saying it's worth more than the sum of its parts

(@Groundhog Day: we'll come to it, but to summarise briefly: "speculation" isn't "rumour" and the job of a market report is to say why shares go up and down. What we do here, which is to add a bit more context to the noise, is rather different ...)

11:11 am

Sorry, right. Whitbread .... So, Costa's in slowdown, Premier Inn's looking pretty stretched .....

Are the activists taking a more active interest in one of the market's stalest conglomerate stories because they think Alison Brittain is more vulnerable?

BE11:14am

I don't know. To be clear. But, since nothing else has changed with the story that I can see, that's one possible option.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, let me drag out all the usual breakup maths. We've done it a thousand times before but I guess we can do it again.

Groundhog Day Note that even Betaville author has answered the tweet by now and said it was a misrepresentation of what he wrote (while adding more clickbait)
DJ @Groundhog Day - crikey. any idea what the original betaville report said?
BE11:15am

Morgan Stanley:

Badger Am i mistaken or is there a hint of copying alphaville look and feel on the site referenced in the tweet?
BE11:16am

Elliott's 6% stake takes WTB's activist interest to greater than 9%, and its
reported push for a Costa demerger differs from the company's current strategy, likely leading to further speculation, which should support the shares. But Costa is only 25% of profit/EV, so investors need to believe in more for outsized returns.

Groundhog Day @DJ, no, but in my experience Betaville has a bating average that is worse than random selection... And given he wants 10k or so for a subscription, I find it absurd. So I never read it. If he is right it almost always seems coincidence. Plus not a big fan of pure "click bait" headlines
11:17 am
BE11:17am

(@ROTR: you're in difficult territory right now. Can you ease off talking about peers. I don't want to have to zap anything.)

BE11:18am

A Costa demerger seems the simplest route to break-up. The Sunday Times
article says that Elliott is pushing for a demerger of Costa rather than "any other financial engineering" (Sachem Head was reported as pressing Whitbread to sell off its property). We have discussed before the various options open to Whitbread if it were to change its structure (e.g. here and here). A demerger of Costa should require minimal additional cost, and a demerger rather than a sale could remove the risk the business is sold too cheaply at a time it is being turned
around in the UK and upping investment internationally. A disposal of hotel realestate risks taking on more expensive long-term leases, losing control of the asset / product, and reducing investment opportunities. A disposal of the Pub Restaurants risks dis-synergies given nearly all are co-located adjacent to a Premier Inn. So Elliott's proposal seems relatively lower risk, in our view.

FATDAZ BTW all did anyone else see comments about the recent Goldman Biotech note asking is single cure a viable biz plan https://gizmodo.com/goldman-sachs-analysts-question-whether-curing-patients-1825244673Creates a moral hazard / dilema for Drug cos and investors no ?
RA Ben Harrington actually replied to that tweet saying it wasnt an accurate representation of what he wrote.
Groundhog Day @RA: INaccurate
BBOC Who's going to take up the reins at WPP with Sorrel out? Sheryl Sandberg?
BE11:19am

MOST's Whitbread valuation's on £41 on EV/EBITDA and £44 on P/E

FATDAZ do you think he is an aire to the jacket fortune :)
11:19 am
BE11:19am

(@ROTR: final warning)

Pharma @FATDAZ, for shareholders, selling to PE who then struggle because they paid too much actually sounds like a good plan.
BE11:20am

So .... you need more than just breaking out Costa to get a solid return.

FATDAZ @Pharma fairpoint re Existing WTB holders Costa must be a saturation point in UK by now
BE11:21am

Costa is c. 25% of group EBITDA and EV, so in itself a separation would be
unlikely to produce outsized returns, unless it were sold for a significant
premium post demerger (every 1x is c. 140p per share or 3.5% to the share price), and/or Hotels are also rerated (every 1x is c. 400p per share or 10% to the share price).

DJ interesting read on Conviviality - https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/business/revealed-how-not-to-run-a-p-up-at-an-off-licence-cr2h8037b
Fox Vectura up 30% in 2 weeks! ?cause
11:21 am
BE11:22am

And Panmure:

BE11:22am

CEO’s tone has become noticeably more conciliatory to shareholder demand, which will make next week’s
finals (25 April) interesting. Break up arguments cover two main scenarios 1) Costa spin-off, and 2) Op
Co/Prop Co of Premier Inn hotel assets. Putting PI on 11x EBITDA and Pub/Restaurants on 8x, the
current Whitbread share price values Costa at just 7.5x EBITDA, vs. Starbucks 13x. We estimate each
turn of Costa EV/EBITDA is worth £235m/130p per share. The challenge is why sell now when LFLs are
flatling and market is worried about the high st, having rebutted demands to sell over the last 8 years
when LFL averaged mid-single digit growth? If CEO Alison Brittain can demonstrate self-help initiatives
are working and Costs LFLs inflect in H2 then Costa would be primed for sale. The other angle,
spinning off property, feels like a non-starter given than i) SLBs would increase operational gearing, ii)
the Board consistently advocate benefits of freehold ownership, iii) WTB doesn’t really need the cash
proceeds.

Groundhog Day Wait - is "ROTR" me? Sorry if I offended anyone. None of my chat messages are meant that way. Just giving 1) an opinion about a source (and I will refrain from doing that if it offends in the future!) and then 2) corrected that Ben replied to the tweet mentioned above saying it was INaccurate as opposed to accurate. So @Be if you meant me - sorry.
BE11:23am

Anyway, you get the idea. There's a counter argument here that activist funds generally, and Elliott in particular, are getting outsized.

cracklenpop Any SOTP calcs for WPP?
joachim Shire disposal at 9 x revenues compared with its overall valuation of 2x. Takeda is on to something.

Okay, on Shire:

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,644, up 37.5 (+1.04%), High: 3,732, Low: 3,625, Volume: 703.60k
BornCynic Morning BE - getting ready to zap us already. I take it you had a good weekend :)

I've read quite a lot this morning that the sale of oncology complicates the potential purchase by Takeda .....

11:25 am
BE11:26am

... doesn't it do the opposite?

BE11:26am

It's, effectively, made Shire $2.4bn cheaper. Because you don't pay a takeover premium for cash, which can be returned pre completion.

BE11:27am

Liberum:

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Our NPV had c.$3bn in for this which equates to a c.1% dilution to our asset value. In terms of earnings the transaction is likely to be broadly neutral assuming buybacks mitigate the c.5% dilution from the sale.

BE11:27am

Strategically this is not a big move given the small size and is not entirely unexpected given Shire is clearly sub-scale in oncology. We view the implications for the ongoing Takeda situation as limited given we don’t think oncology was the key element in Takeda’s interest.

cracklenpop @FATDAZ break-up looks inevitable - Sorrell was Tito to WPP's Yugoslavia
BE11:28am

And Jefferies:

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Shire has entered into a definitive agreement to sell its oncology business to Servier (private) for $2.4bn cash. This franchise includes Oncaspar for ALL, ex-US rights to Onivyde for pancreatic cancer, and other pipeline assets. The cash consideration represents 9.2x the $262m 2017 sales or c.17x the $140m contribution EBITDA (before direct and indirect costs). The valuation is just above our $2.32bn 178p/share NPV, representing 4.2% of the c.$54.5bn 4200p/share sum-of-the-parts valuation. We note the process to divest the oncology business reportedly began in January, with multiple strategic buyers identified across the US, Europe and Japan.

BE11:28am

Recall on 28 March, Takeda (4502 JP, JPY5016, NC) confirmed that it is considering an offer to acquire Shire. We see the possible strategic fit given the company's focus therapeutic areas of oncology, gastrointestinal and neuroscience, with Shire bolstering the latter two franchises. Furthermore, Shire's leading global position in rare diseases would likely be attractive for most large pharma/biotech, particularly given the long duration assets in immunoglobulin and enzyme replacement therapy (ERT). However, given the ongoing complex integration of Baxalta since June 2016, an acquisition at this time carries incremental risks, in our view.

GBKrona @BE - wonder how critical is the (limited) SHP oncology franchise to Takeda?Totally buy your point on making SHP cheaper - and the price/sales sets a lower boundary on valuation in case Takeda does not go ahead and make an offer.
Mouselet Good morning misc assorted people
BE11:29am

But with the usual boilerplate about Takeda being wee.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

We note Takeda's current market cap is around $37bn, down c.6% since disclosing the potential bid, which compares to Shire's c.$47bn but $66bn EV including $19.1bn Net Debt at YE2017. Hence, we presume Takeda would need a significant equity raise to acquire Shire, suggesting a "merger" is perhaps better terminology, which may raise hurdles to the successful completion of any future deal.

We continue to believe other approaches from larger peers (on either side of the Atlantic) remain less likely. We also note that a preliminary back-of-envelope analysis suggests the exit will still be very slightly EPS dilutive (c1%, pre any buybacks) given the low present cost of debt. Nonetheless we believe today’s news is likely to be received as a supportive event for valuation, noting also the reference to potential buybacks once the Takeda offer period elapses.

BE11:42am

BE11:42am

Here's Numis:

Miss Piggy to do what he has done isn't Martin Sorrel a genius? It seems we like to pull our great ones down.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

We expect the group to consider internal and external candidates and believe Sir Martin will be hard to replace with one person. The succession has led to questions over the size and scope of WPP and we can see a change of management accelerating the current process of reducing overlap and increasing flexibility. Although we would not rule out a margin reset, we do not view WPP's margins as out of step with the industry given its functional and geographic split, in addition to a reporting structure which increases margins relative to peers both by reducing the numerator and increasing the denominator. We do see scope for the group to put dividend increases and
buybacks into abeyance given its already high payout ratio and leverage at the top end of its target debt corridor. Our base case is for a new management team to
continue and refine the existing strategy, though we acknowledge that any group without a CEO is vulnerable to a bid approach in the interregnum.

BE11:43am

And Citi.

cracklenpop @BE Bob 'give no' Quarta living up to his name
BE11:43am

It is hard to understate the influence Sir Martin Sorrell has had on the entire marketing industry let alone WPP. In the early years, Sir Martin’s role was a portfolio manager, deciding what areas WPP should have exposure to. More recently, his role has been more
focused on making sure the various parts of the portfolio work together and
acting as a figurehead/ spokesperson for the group. The new CEO will need that same combination of skills. In literally the last year, WPP has been seen by many to be losing its way. Against the backdrop of an improving macro
environment, organic growth has been slowing. Anyone coming in to take over
the CEO role at WPP will be entirely focused on turning this round. The slow fix is fairly straightforward in that it is the existing group strategy. The quick fix is to look at asset disposals as a way of managing the group to faster growth, something that Sir Martin was loathe to consider. It is not clear whether the current margin targets or dividend payout will survive a change of management. But then again, valuation is so depressed (10x 2018E P/E) we think value will out. We rate WPP as a Buy.

FATDAZ the other question i surely will Sir martin set up round the corner in anew tech savvy lean mean advertising machine sure he would find backers in VC land
11:44 am
BE11:45am

(@Miss Piggy: if we are arguing that he's a genius, I can only suggest that he could perhaps have dedicated his life to something more noble than rattling a stick in a swill bucket.)

joachim WPP facing secular challenges re zero based budgeting, growth of in house and disintermediation by FB and Google who share 85% of online ad market
BE11:45am

And Panmure.

Miss Piggy hahaha lol
nichoman bit of smurfit pleaz?
BE11:45am

After Sorrell’s exit and interim replacement by two internal COO’s, WPP is now firmly in play. But no
easy solutions here. Not really a turnaround situation (core business already experiencing structural
pressures from digital disruption, co v tightly run in terms of costs & margins, will struggle in upcoming pitches in the near term, Sorrell can set up in competition). Not an easy break-up situation (definitely has surplus assets, eg. market research, ad tech, healthcare, other specialist) but hard to argue disposals would drive much re-rating (eg in mkt research, Nielsen/IPSOS trade on 9.3x/8.4x
ebitda vs WPP currently on 7.9x ebitda 18e). Possible takeover target (for private equity to break up, for Accenture/Deloittes to get much bigger in digital marketing, for Dentsu maybe among existing competitors) – but big bite for any of these at c$34bn EV/c10x ebitda to acquire

Soundbuy Ahhhhhh..........quick google tells me George Orwell
11:47 am
BE11:47am

And Credit Suisse, just for good measure.

BE11:47am

Due to the centralized way
Sir Martin Sorrell ran the company his departure raises the risk of a) account
losses, b) talent leakage, c) break-up and sale of some divisions and d) a
deep restructuring with a great deal of cost and uncertainty. In our view all of
the above would have happened anyway at the point the CEO chose to
leave. In our view the company is likely to eventually adopt a similar strategy
to Publicis based on the convergence of marketing and consulting.
